- eat decent portions. i like using a benchmark between 400-600 calories per meal three times a day and 300 calories worth of snacks
- exercising for at least an hour and doing toning excercises to get a skinnier look but i also do cardio like watlking which is extremely helpful
-drink lots of water!! sometimes you're not hungry, you're dehydrated! i drink at least three liters per day and its really easy to do so if you use a 1.5 liter bottle. i end up drinking more!
- very gross, but i keep my bowels active and eat foods to help me poop. it helps reduce the amount of bloating you have and i try and do it every day with the occasional day without pooping

This comment section clearly show how uneducated some people are, saying the classic myths over and over again.
Let me make it simple: Caloric Deficit=weight loss. That’s it.
No need for keto diet, avoiding carbs, cardio (altho it’s overrated for weight loss it’s obviously helpful for being healthy), only eating “boring” food( altho will make you feel fuller, you could eat ice cream every single day and still lose weight if stays on a deficit, however you will be hungrier. That’s why the typical diets are rich in vegetables and fruits since they are low calories and will keep you full and satisfied while fast food is the exact opposite, thats why you are overweight in the first place since you were on a caloric surplus)
Bonus: There will be a point once you eat the same amount of calories in your deficit that you will no longer lose weight, your body adapts at the caloric intake you consume. Thats why once you see you are stuck at a certain weight while on a deficit, you must decrease your calories or increase cardio in order to continue your weight loss. Also please don’t do an extreme caloric deficit since it will affect your metabolism and you will actually drop your BPM, it’s very dangerous.
Yeah that’s it.

For some individuals, the ketogenic diet is an extraordinary choice for weight reduction. It is altogether different and permits the individual on the eating routine to eat an eating regimen that comprises of food varieties that you may not anticipate.

So the ketogenic diet, or keto, is an eating regimen that comprises of low carbs and high fat. The number of diets are there where you can get your day going with bacon and eggs, heaps of it, then, at that point follow it up with chicken wings for lunch and afterward steak and broccoli for supper. That may sound unrealistic for some. Well on this eating routine this is an extraordinary day of eating and you kept the standards consummately with that dinner plan.

At the point when you eat a low measure of carbs your body gets placed into a condition of ketosis. This means your body consumes fat for energy. How low of a measure of carbs do you have to eat to get into ketosis? Indeed, it differs from one individual to another, yet it is a sure thing to remain under 25 net carbs. Many would propose that when you are in the "enlistment stage" which is the point at which you are really placing your body into ketosis, you should remain under 10 net carbs.

In the event that you don't know what net carbs are, let me help you. Net carbs are the measure of carbs you eat short the measure of dietary fiber. So if on the day you eat an aggregate of 35 grams of net carbs and 13 grams of dietary fiber, your net carbs for the day would be 22. Adequately basic, correct?

So next to weight reduction what else is acceptable about keto? Well numerous individuals talk about their improved mental lucidity on when on the eating regimen. Another advantage is having an increment in energy. One more is a diminished hunger.

The only way to lose weight with a diet, is by having a healthy relationship with food. Never exclude certain foods from your diet, do watch your calorie intake but don't be obsessive about it. I went through a period in which I'd get angry at myself if I ate more than 1200kcal, which is horrifying. If you don't like exercise but still want to lose weight: calculate your BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate), it is the calories you burn in a day without moving, at all. Then go down a max. of 25% from that number and stick to that number of calories 80% of the time (you can have treats if that fits within that plan). Drink enough water to keep your body hydrated. If you can/want, go on walks or try to include some exercises. Don't get too hard on yourself if you ate more than you should've, just try to not overdo it when you feel like eating a bit more (and if you're having a family dinner party for holidays, please feel free to indulge, what you do in one day will not influence what you do the rest of the time).

What You Should Know Before You Start A Weight-loss Plan?

You may want to lose weight for personal reasons. Or you may need to lose weight to improve your health. It can reduce your risk of certain conditions, such heart disease and type 2 diabetes. It can lower your blood pressure and total cholesterol level. It also can relieve symptoms and prevent injuries related to being overweight.

There are several factors that can affect your efforts to lose weight. These include making changes to your diet, exercise, and lifestyle. There are tools and tips to keep you on track. In addition, you should know what not to do. Talk to your doctor before you begin a new plan. He or she can help you customize a program and safely monitor your progress. Even small changes can make a big difference in your health.

If you're overweight, then I suggest starting with a keto diet first. Basically fatty meat with veges, as much as you want to get your body habituated to burning fat as a fuel source. If you want to lose excess weight (fat), then you have to train your metabolism to get used to burning fat. No sugar, no bread, no noodles, no carbs AT ALL. Carbs have an interesting metabolic effect since if it's not used soon, then it get stored as fat.



Make sure you're eating enough salt, potassium and magnesium in the diet: critical. All available as supplements. After 2 weeks on the keto diet, you'll notice that your appetite has diminished and your cravings for random food goes down to zero. Next step is intermittent fasting - so have your last meal at 6 pm. Don't eat until the next day @ 10 am.



Keep on doing this for a week, then have your first meal at 12 noon (so 18 hours with no food). Just a regular keto meal, enough to make you feel full. 1 week (or 2 weeks) later, have your first meal @ 2 pm. Only eat at 6 if you're hungry.



When you're ready, eat only 1 meal @ 1 pm. Now you're on the OMAD (one-meal-a-day) fasting routine.
Record how you feel, energy levels, cravings, sleep quality.



Then attempt a 48 hour fast, and finally a 5 day fast. BUT! You MUST drink lots of water with potassium, magnesium and salt throughout the fast. Usually the first day is easy but day 2 and day 3 can be really tough. If you don't feel good at any stage, then go back to OMAD fasting. Fasting is not unhealthy if you do it right - think about it: our ancestors didn't have access to supermarkets/refrigeration and going without food for days was not unusual.



Dr Berg, Dr Mindy Pelz and Dr Fung all have solid videos on keto, intermittent fasting and long term fasting. Check them out

Hundreds of thousands of success stories have come from intermittent fasting.

9 tips to lose weight fast / Tips to lose weight. Losing weight is difficult but not impossible. You will learn how to lose weight in this video. Losing weight is important for our health. This video will give you weight loss tips that you can implement very easily in your life, improve your overall health and lose weight naturally. So let's discover these powerful tips for losing weight.
1. Drink a lot of water
Drinking more water decreases the amount of fat stored in the body. If you do not drink enough water, your kidneys can transmit most of your unfinished work to your liver. One of the functions of your liver is to help your body burn stored fat for energy and it can not fully accomplish this job if it also needs to do kidney work.
2. drink green tea
Studies show that you can burn 35 to 43% more fat during the day if you drink 3 to 5 cups of green tea. If you do not have the time to make your own green tea, you can simply take a green tea diet pill supplement.
3. Be more active
Adding a little physical activity to your daily routine will help you lose weight faster than you can imagine. Try to find ways to gradually add physical activity to your daily routine. All the extra calories you burn doing these activities add to the weight loss.
4. Training early in the morning
As soon as you wake up in the morning, train at least 30 minutes to an hour. Studies show that morning training has been shown to burn up to 3 times more fat than training at any other time of the day.
5. chew your food longer
You should chew everything you eat at least 8 to 12 times. Eat slowly. Your body does not realize that you are tired of eating until several minutes after eating it.
6. Do not sit for more than 4 hours
According to researchers at the University of Missouri, sitting or being virtually inactive for more than 4 hours slows the metabolism, thus facilitating fat retention. To avoid this, try to get up at least 10 minutes every two hours.
7. sleep well
Do not sleep too long or too little time, because according to a study conducted by researchers at Laval University in Quebec, people who slept more than 8 hours and those who slept less than 6 hours were more likely than people sleeping 7 to 8 hours normal.
8. walk more
If you do not have the time to do an exercise program, buy a pedometer and try to take 10,000 steps a day to burn an extra 100 calories or more each day, until you lose more than 10 pounds a year. minimal effort. from you.
9. Lift heavier weights to burn fat faster
Here are the 9 tips for losing weight fast.

Sorry for this long post but it contains useful information about losing weight.

I agree with reducing plate sizes and counting calories, but low fat foods are actually not that good for you. With low fat foods its flavor is reduced so to make it taste better they add sugar; one of the main fat causing foods.

Regular foods are better than low fat unless you are looking to gain muscle instead of lose weight.

The best thing to do is spread the amount of daily calories in small amounts of food with 2-3 hours in between and avoiding drinks that have extra calories because most of them are sugar. Also having your last meal 3 hours before you go to sleep so the food is fully digested and the energy used while sleeping is from the fat not from the food. Finally reducing the amount of carbs and fill it with more protein, natural sugars, and vegetables. Unless again you are looking to gain muscle not lose weight.

And remember if you are exercising to lose weight you might gain muscle, which weight more than fat. To be honest you don't need serious exercise to lose weight, just changing your diet to change your resting metabolism and make sure the leptin levels in your body and normal.

important to remember
FOR WEIGHT LOSS:
stay under your daily calorie limit. it is a scientific fact that if you burn more calories than you consume (given there are no serious medical conditions), you WILL lose weight. if you burn 2,000 calories a day and eat 1,800 calories of junk food, you WILL drop pounds because of the deficit.

FOR HEALTH:
weight loss and health are extremely different. health involves focusing on the micros you need, and insuring that around 80% of your diet is composed of lean protein, good carbs, and healthy fats. 200 calories of veggies are much healthier and much more filling than 200 calories of cake.

all in all, for the best possible lifestyle, maintain a healthy amount of calories composed of good foods for your body. health and weight loss will come hand in hand if you take some slow steps.

I disagree about eating breakfast. Perhaps eating breakfast makes some people less hungry for the rest of the day, but I know that for other people (like me) if I eat breakfast at say, 7am, I want to eat lunch by 11am, then I am hungry enough for dinner by 6-7pm. If I don't eat breakfast, I don't get hungry for lunch until about 3pm, then I am hungry enough for dinner by 6-7pm just like before. Possibly the difference is between people who wake up feeling hungry (who would enjoy eating breakfast) and people who wake up feeling vaguely nauseous.

Intermittent fasting is pretty great.  Exercise during your fasting window and you're using your fat reserves as energy.  Eat during an 8 hour window (a reasonable diet) and you're good to go.

I started losing weight about six months ago. Excluding what I've gained in muscle mass from regular exercise, (about 10 pounds) I've lost over 125 pounds of body fat. The most important step for weight loss is to tell yourself that you can do it and that nothing will stop you. Once you're able to do that, you'll be able to do everything else. I've counted calories, learned about good fats, bad fats, carbs, vitamins, sugars, etc... And I did it all because I had a goal. If you decide to make the change to be thin, you need to be ready to change your whole life.

When all you want is pizza and potato chips, remind yourself that eating steamed vegetables with a side of rice instead isn't just being healthier, it's also being responsible, disciplined, and smart. Making yourself thin and healthy helps you do more with your life. Not only can you do more and feel better, but you do more for the people around you by being healthy. You can do more with people, you can be around longer for your friends and family, and you can even reduce the strain on your country's healthcare system by requiring less avoidable care, like heart medication, heart surgeries, diabetes medicine, etc.

It's worth it to be thin.

I stopped watching this as soon as they recommended low fat dairy. Dairy products depletes the calcium from your bones. Like any other animal derived protein-rich food, milk has a positive potential renal acid load which triggers a protective biological reaction to neutralize all the damaging acidic protein before it reaches the kidneys. The body is designed for survival, so it sacrifices bone density to protect the kidneys and urinary tract because the latter are essential to survival. And the most readily available source of acid neutralizer is in the bones. So even though milk contains calcium, it ends up sapping your bones of that crucial mineral.

This video should really mention how important hydration is. Drink more water. I can't stress that enough. Not only is it important for bodily functions, but your body also has a hard time telling you "hey, I could use a little water here". So it feels like you're hungry, even though your body might just be trying to tell you it needs a drink. If you're hungry, drink some water first. If the hunger feeling goes away, you were just a little thirsty. Otherwise eat something. I'm not saying go and chug a gallon right now, and we actually get a lot of water from the food we eat, but increase the amount of water you drink and give your metabolism a boost.

Calcium is definitely necessary, but dairy is actually a bad source of calcium. While there is ample amounts of calcium in dairy products, the acids in animal products take our bodies out of the alkaline state. To compensate, the body releases more calcium to balance, taking away calcium from where it's needed. Essentially, it's like someone handing you $100 while they swipe $200 from your back pocket. It's why people who consume high amounts of dairy products are more likely to develop osteoporosis and other bone issues than those who consume little or no dairy products. Some examples of good sources of calcium are things such as broccoli, collard greens, kale, oranges, bok choy, and almonds. :)

I enjoy your videos. I do have to point out an error...

Eating breakfast doesn't boost your metabolism for the rest of the day. There is a slight metabolic boost through digestion but this happens anytime you eat. It only last while your food is being digested.

What's important to realize is that an boost in metabolism doesn't come close to offsetting the calories eaten. If you eat 200 calories for breakfast, around 15% of those calories will be used for digestion. That still leaves you with 170 calories.

So yes, metabolism did increase a bit, for a short time. But your calorie consumption increased more than the calories burned off.

"Don't skip breakfast" Actually, that's not true anymore. It's a myth. Science debunked this. (Breakfast cereals are by far the worst breakfast meal you can have, alongside coke and pizza). Only eat when you're hungry. Some people feel better and even loose more weight skiping breakfast.
"adding more low-fat dairy" - False. Even though fatties has 2.4x calories than carbohidrates or protein, it has a incredible satiating effect. Furthermore, fatties are really important, even the saturated ones. Calcium is really great, but it's almost useless without magnesium. So, the best calcium comes from fruits and greens leaves in general, not from the dairy.
"count your calories" - FALSE. While tracking your foods helps you to loose weight (science really proves it), counting or limiting your calories isn't a good idea. Instead, take about about the macronutrients in your food. 150 calories from proteins are different from 150 calories from carbs. Calories ALONE do not says nothing.

The best way I've found to lose weight is just to cook from whole ingredients whenever possible (the amount of sugar in even a can of shop-bought tomato soup is insane), plan meals properly so that I have them set out in advance, and then just eat when I'm hungry.

I get a little bit annoyed whenever a TV show or book talks about breakfast, lunch and dinner as if these are totally intrinsic things (like sleeping for a single stretch of 8 hours a night, which is also a fairly modern, culturally-specific tradition). People don't all eat three set meals per day all over the world, and it's pretty arbitrary that we do. The pattern of breakfast, lunch and dinner don't work well for everyone, and if they don't work for you then IMO it's a good idea to experiment with different eating times and portion sizes and find out what works best for you. Some people are happy with two meals, some prefer six, and in my experience, a big breakfast makes me want more food throughout the day, rather than less. If I binge on junk food, it's just because I can - e.g. it's in the house, or I haven't brought a packed lunch to work. This is why it's good to plan and portion out meals in advance!

The "don't skip breakfast" thing isn't fuly accurate. It's best to listen to your biological rythm. If you're usually hungrier at night and not very hungry during the day it's better to listen to your body and eat more at the time it tells you to eat more or less. That isn't to say you should repeatedly skip meals between that time - but if a tiny bowl of leftovers and some yogurt is enough for you to feel full then that's really all you need, and you can save your calories for eating a larger meal when you're actually hungry. Also, it's good to have once-in-a-blue-moon days where you skip meals altogether (that is, those occasional days where you just didn't have time to eat are more than enough - don't purposefully starve yourself!). the reason those days are important is because the human body is still very very very much set to "caveman"; it doesn't _know_the living conditions have changed, so our body is still set and expecting times of plenty and times of starvation. The rare day where you skip a meal or two helps to keep your body from freaking out and getting all confused at the lack of starvation.
Also, side tip, foods that contain healthy fats like avocado and peanut butter are great sources of energy for exercise, while containing fairly low calorie counts ;)

A lot of these are crap, including the idea that fat should be avoided and that everyone should eat breakfast.  Skipping breakfast is not synonymous with starving oneself, and not everyone's metabolism is timed the same way.  Just because you can somehow tie a "tip" to some scientific fact or study doesn't mean that the tip makes sense for everyone in the entire context of human metabolism.  Exercise is good for being healthy, but for many people it is not an effective way to lose weight.  Exercise will help you lose weight if you tend to eat less after you exercise.  If you tend to eat more after you exercise, it probably won't.  The best tip is the small plate size.

More of this "low fat foods will help you lose weight," "calories in/calories out actually follows from the first law of thermodynamics" pseudoscience?

Research fructose, insulin sensitivity, and leptin sensitivity if you're actually interested in maintaining a thin physique while feeling full at the end of meals. Exercise is healthy, but the mere act of burning calories through activity WILL NOT HELP YOU LOSE WEIGHT. (Your body accounts for a deficit of energy by making you feel more hungry. Any amount of time spent in starvation or semistarvation is calorically repaid with interest; you will end up gaining more weight after your transient period of thinness if you attempt to lose fat by not eating when you're hungry – don't yo-yo diet.) The benefits of exercise come from the hormonal changes it brings (regarding norepinephrine, serotonin, and testosterone), and exercise itself is not necessary to maintain a healthy weight; just look at the French.

tl;dr:
Avoid sugar at all costs.

You don't actually need dairy. You can get the same vitamins from most vegetables, including calcium. Humans are the only species of animals that continue to consume milk products after infancy. Not just any milk products, but milk products from a completely different species (cow, goat).. it's just plain weird. Don't get me wrong, I love cheese. But I hate how a SCIENCE page of all places is supporting the myth that we "need" dairy. We do not need dairy in order to obtain nutrients like calcium. Vegetables like celery, broccoli, spinach, kelp, soybeans, and okra are very high in calcium. Almonds and brazil nuts are also high in calcium. You can get Vitamin D and potassium from a whole slew of other fruits and veggies. Dairy is hard for the body to digest. In the US, most people can digest it just fine minus those with intolerance. But this is because most young babies and children are conditioned to tolerate milk byproducts from a very young age, as young as 1 years old.

God this video is so wrong on so many levels. Studies have debunked the entire "don't skip meals, especially breakfast" hypothesis. Not only that, but they put a bowl of refined carbohydrates which gets converted into sugar and spikes insulin as their breakfast. Without the naturally occurring fat in the milk the sugars get absorbed much more quickly, once again spiking insulin and storing fat! Then they use the whole the fact that milk has calcium smh. Green leafy vegetables have calcium that's even more digestible! Soups are great like chicken and vegetable soup. People who journal what they eat isn't the same as counting calories. Reducing your plate size is a good tip. Sleep deprivation and stress definitely make it harder to loss weight. Intermittent fasting (skipping breakfast), has been shown to be quite healthy, actually. It increases growth hormone levels (helping you build muscle while you lose fat), makes it easier to restrict calories (as long as you resist the urge to load up on calorie dense food once you do eat - have a bowl of soup first and that shouldn't be a problem), and increases insulin sensitivity making it easier to control hunger in the future. As your body desperately tries to get food, you become more alert. And protein from your muscle is only used as a source of energy as a last resort after about 2-3 days of fasting.

In other words, the amount of food has as much if not more to do than the calories of that food with how hungry you feel. This is why drinking more water also helps satiate hunger, and why bariatric surgery and lap bands work.

It's also why the stuff about eating breakfast is old hat. In a healthy person, insulin levels are fine in the morning. If you don't feel hungry, it's fine to skip--unless you are always tired in the morning and need that extra energy. But caffeine can also help that.

Hunger is not purely caloric but also volumetric.

Let's say you go for a 2 mile run. You might burn 200 calories, maybe 300. Then you think, "Wow! That run made me hungry! I'm going to go and make myself a sandwich/bowl of pasta/whatever." Then in terms of calories alone (yeah it's good for your heart etc.), your run has been essentially wasted.

Your body will always try to make your input to output ratio /at least/ 1:1; you will not lose weight if all you do is exercise and have no willpower.

I hate when I go somewhere and people serve me soups because of that (especially the thin crap most people/companies call soup - hint: if there's more liquor than anything else, you're doing it wrong). As for counting calories, that would just end in my death.

I rarely bother to eat, so if I set to fuck around with counting calories when I did...

Therefore using a smaller plate would only assure I eat 2 smaller plates minimum for every 1 I would've had otherwise because not filling the second plate up isn't an option. That second plate would look like it wouldn't take long to eat, regardless of whether I've already had a plate or not so it would have to be full as well.

Making the plate much smaller still than even suggested here would only serve to further multiply how many I will need to eat...

I can guarantee, that decreasing plate size would not work for me.

I have never felt full, nor hungry. Since I don't have those cues, I have to go with my 3 T system. Taste, texture, and time. If it tastes good and has a good texture as well as takes a while to eat (or at least seems to) then I am satisfied. Otherwise I must continue to eat until specifically the "time" has been satisfied.

Time however, is not measured in actual time, but in how long it LOOKS like it will take...

Kicking stuff, placing repeated pressure on your bones in moderation  does promote bone strength because the body reacts to pressure by strengthening bone. This is why astronauts in microgravity lose bone density and exercise prevents osteoporosis.

Also, it's not a good idea for most overweight people to run. Even jogging can be harmful to their knees because of the extra strain. These people are also likely not in the best of shape, so running would be painful and even dangerous strain on their heart. Walking, swimming, weight lifting are all better ways for an out of shape, very overweight person to start.

Weight loss is complex and unique - that's why the video is called "weight loss tips" and not "secrets of weight loss". The various causes of weight gain will determine where body fat deposits, and if the weight stays on due to something like hormones, then weight loss will be particularly difficult. We yawn when our body has built up too much CO2 in our blood... It's a natural way to flood our lungs with fresh air and remove the excess CO2...We open our mouths because that allows our body to breathe in much more fresh air than we do during a normal breath. The muscles in your throat also pull back to fully open your windpipe to really flush in fresh air.

We usually build up excess CO2 during long periods of inactivity - hence it's usually when you're tired or bored, but not always.

Here's a practical weight loss tip. If your weight is steady but you would like to lose a few pounds, cutting out 100 calories a day will take off around 5 lbs a month. But there's a catch. The larger you are the more calories you need to stay at a steady weight. So if you stay at the new constant calorie level eventually you will stop losing weight when you reach equilibrium. You need to decrease your total calories (or increase exercise) the more weight you lose. That's why diets fail.

Life must be tough out there on that limb by yourself, looking down at the rest of us, basking in the super intelligence that blesses you and not the rest of us.

But the number one thing to remember is DON'T COUNT CALORIES. The act of counting calories will raise your stress levels and make you feel guilty, causing you to skip a meal, or worse, eating low calorie things might make you think you can eat A LOT of low calorie things, which is quite counterproductive. And this is coming from someone who spent 2 years in 'Eating Disorder' classes with anorexics bulimics and over-eaters.

Secondly, not eating breakfast starves your body longer, increasing the DESIRE to eat high calorie foods, which makes you more LIKELY to overeat. While it comes back to calories, it's the mechanisms of your brain and physiology that drive your body.

Calories in, calories out AND metabolism (calories burned).
